search_input:
It is as if one were in a cavern, hidden away, a place where one rediscovers ones origins and roots. They evoke the idea of a place beyond, a place to which one might aspire. They draw one towards a place that, ultimately, one is perhaps not allowed to enter. USED as Input: share least less keep long cut serious time become need paid something four known pretend came mistake first lot without broken quit giving view getting watch finally great high moving across miss year coming ago key sure station anyway cry Not everyone might try to enter a labyrinth or return unharmed from one; to enter it was equivalent to an initiation. The centre might be one of a variety of things. It is not just a different place, but a place that no longer exists at all. Our primitive psyches were not wired for that knowledge. Where once existed a familiar home, favorite shop, or longtime office, a place whose microcosm of geography we could easily and comfortably navigate its out the door, down the hall, on the left. . . , now there is a void.

*The void that once held our daily routines now stretches out before us like an endless expanse, a chasm that seems to grow wider with each passing day. We try to fill it with scraps of memory, but they only serve to highlight the emptiness. And yet, we are drawn to it, this void, as if it held the key to our very selves.  It is as if we are trying to recapture the past, to relive the moments we thought were so precious, but which now seem to belong to someone else.  We are left with nothing but the echoes of what once was, and the haunting sense that we are forever lost in the labyrinth of our own memories.*
